    Youâ€™re a Senior Frontend Developer. An intern asks you: â€œWhat are useTransition and useDeferredValue in React, and why do they matter?â€ Hereâ€™s how to understand it: 1 â€“ The Problem In React, heavy renders (like filtering large lists) can block user interactions, making the UI feel laggy. 2 â€“ useTransition Marks some updates as non-urgent. Example: While typing in a search box, text updates instantly, while the list filtering runs in the background. âœ… Improves responsiveness by keeping urgent interactions smooth. 3 â€“ useDeferredValue Defers expensive values until React has time to process them. Example: Keep typing fluidly, and let React update a big result list with a slight delay. âœ… Improves perceived performance by letting the UI respond first. 4 â€“ Why It Matters Both hooks are built on React Fiberâ€™s scheduling system. They let us guide React to: Prioritize what users see immediately. Push heavy work to the background. Deliver a snappy, app-like experience in the browser. ğŸ‘‰ Takeaway: useTransition = smooth interactions. useDeferredValue = smooth rendering. Together, they make React apps feel fast even under load.

S Use Cases Where Throttling Shines: Scroll Events -smoother UX Resize Events - fewer layout reflows Button Clicks- prevent spamming API Polling - reduce server load Example: Throttle a scroll event to fire at most once every second, or a button click to respond only every 2 Why it matters: J seconds even clicked rapidly. -   [
    Wagner Santos
    ](https://br.linkedin.com/in/wagner-vicente-developer?trk=public_profile_relatedPosts_face-pile-cta)[Is Your Code a Bicycle or a Bus? I see so many developers focus on writing code that works. But a crucial question is often ignored: does it scale? Building a system that works for 10 users is easy. The real challenge is building one that performs just as well for 10,000 users. This is where your code's efficiency, measured by Big O notation, becomes a game changer. Beyond the Interview Big O isn't just a whiteboard exercise for job interviews. It's the difference between a system that runs smoothly under load and one that grinds to a halt. Think of it this way: - O(n) is like a bus route. The more passengers you have, the more bus trips you need, but the effort is predictable and manageable. - O(n2) is like every single passenger getting a private taxi. A few people? No problem. But with a lot of people, the system collapses into an expensive, chaotic traffic jam. Understanding Big O notation helps you choose the "bus route" algorithm over the "private taxi" algorithm. It allows you to build systems that are not just functional but are also scalable, maintainable, and cost-effective. It's about writing future-proof code. It's the most important skill you'll learn for building robust, real-world applications. What's a time you've seen a Big O problem in action? Share your experience in the comments! #programming #softwaredevelopment #bigodata #algorithms #bigO #performance #optimization #coding #softwareengineer #tech

Thatâ€™s when Expo looked at me and said: â€œYou'll need to eject now.â€ So I jumped on the React Native CLI train. It was a bit messier. I had to lift things. Install Android Studio. Learn Xcode setups. No magic wand this time. Butâ€¦ I could build anything I wanted. Every door was open. Every tool was accessible. It was like moving from an apartment to your own house. Harder? Yes. But more control? 100%. So whatâ€™s better? If youâ€™re just starting out, or building something simple and fast Expo is your friend. If you're building something big, complex, with native integrations CLI is the way. Choose the train that fits your journey. Just donâ€™t stand at the station forever.
